user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_grow_:
```c
static int lfs_fs_grow_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_size_t block_count) {
    int err;

    if (block_count == lfs->block_count) {
        return 0;
    }

    
#ifndef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    // shrinking is not supported
    LFS_ASSERT(block_count >= lfs->block_count);
#endif
#ifdef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    if (block_count < lfs->block_count) {
        err = lfs_fs_traverse_(lfs, lfs_shrink_checkblock, &block_count, true);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }
#endif

    lfs->block_count = block_count;

    // fetch the root
    lfs_mdir_t root;
    err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // update the superblock
    lfs_superblock_t superblock;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &root, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT, 0, sizeof(superblock)),
            &superblock);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }
    lfs_superblock_fromle32(&superblock);

    superblock.block_count = lfs->block_count;

    lfs_superblock_tole32(&superblock);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &root, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {tag, &superblock}));
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_fs_grow_:
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_size_t
...
typedef struct lfs_mdir {
    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    uint32_t rev;
    lfs_off_t off;
    uint32_t etag;
    uint16_t count;
    bool erased;
    bool split;
    lfs_block_t tail[2];
} lfs_mdir_t
...
typedef struct lfs_superblock {
    uint32_t version;
    lfs_size_t block_size;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
} lfs_superblock_t
...
typedef int32_t lfs_stag_t
...
#define LFS_MKTAG(type, id, size) (((lfs_tag_t)(type)<<20)|((lfs_tag_t)(id)<<10)|(lfs_tag_t)(size))
...
#define LFS_MKATTRS(__VA_ARGS__) (structlfs_mattr[]){__VA_ARGS__},sizeof((structlfs_mattr[]){__VA_ARGS__})/sizeof(structlfs_mattr)
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any constructs that are clearly compiler-specific language extensions as documented by mainstream compilers (GCC, Clang, MSVC, IAR, Keil, etc.). The items that might look non‑standard at first glance are actually standard C features (C99 and later), not compiler extensions:

- The LFS_MKATTRS macro uses a compound literal ((struct lfs_mattr[]){ ... }) and a variadic macro (__VA_ARGS__). Both compound literals and variadic macros are part of the C99 standard, not compiler extensions.
- The use of // single-line comments and the bool type (_Bool/bool from <stdbool.h>) are C99 features as well.
- Bitwise shifts, casts, and the macro LFS_MKTAG are standard C operations, not extensions.
- Conditional compilation (#ifdef / #ifndef) and assert usage via LFS_ASSERT are standard preprocessor and library facilities.

I also noted what appears to be a typo in the provided macro definition text: "structlfs_mattr[]" (missing space) — this looks like a transcription/formatting issue rather than a language extension. If that token really appears in the source it would be a syntax error, not an extension.

If your target toolchain explicitly documents any of the above C99 features as "extensions" (for example, if the project mandates strict C89-only compilers or a particular compiler marks some C99 features as extensions), then those features should be re-evaluated against that compiler's documentation. Based on the code shown and typical compiler documentation, there are no explicit compiler language extensions present to report under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
